Climate change represents one of the most pressing challenges facing our societies, with governments, non-governmental organizations, and other stakeholders emphasizing measures to mitigate its adverse effects. A key scientific challenge is understanding aerosol-cloud interactions, which are a major source of uncertainty in climate change projections. Aerosols affect climate directly by scattering and absorbing solar radiation, and indirectly by altering cloud properties, impacting Earth's energy budget. Increased aerosol concentrations can lead to smaller cloud droplet radii, increasing cloud albedo and reducing precipitation efficiency, while also increasing cloud lifetime.

Climate models can explain complex interactions between aerosols, clouds, and precipitation, but the complexity of the climate system makes it difficult to simulate all processes simultaneously. High-resolution models with smaller grid cells can better represent small-scale processes, but are computationally expensive and can only be run for short periods over limited areas. The ICON-LEM model, for example, requires 13 hours on 300 computer nodes to simulate one hour, at a cost of approximately EUR 100,000 per simulated day.

To address this challenge, we developed machine learning models that leverage satellite observations for long-term global coverage. Our models can capture key processes, such as autoconversion rates, which describe the collision and coalescence of cloud droplets responsible for raindrop formation. We validated our models against simulation data, showing that they can predict autoconversion rates fairly well.

The use of machine learning in climate science has not been fully explored, despite its potential to revolutionize the field. Recent advances in machine learning have led to impressive results in solving challenging problems, and it is conjectured that these advances will enable climate science to make significant progress in understanding aerosol-cloud-precipitation interactions. Our study aims to contribute to this understanding by developing machine learning models that estimate autoconversion rates using satellite observations.

Autoconversion rates have been parameterized in various studies, including Berry [1967], Kessler [1969], and others. Recent studies have also used machine learning to predict autoconversion rates, such as Seifert and Rasp [2020] and Chiu et al. [2021]. Our study differs from existing work by estimating autoconversion rates using machine learning models that leverage satellite observations for global spatial coverage.
